elements.content: Three new coordination polymers, {[Zn(H2Bpz)(Tph)]·1/2(H2Bpz)} n (1), [Zn 2 (H2Bpz)(Bpz)(Iph)] n (2), and {[Zn 2 (H2Bpz)(HBtc) 2 (H2O) 2 ]·7/6(H2O)} n (3) (H2Bpz = 3,3‘,5,5‘-tetramethyl-4,4‘-bipyrazole; H2Tph = terephthalic acid; H2Iph = isophthalic acid; H3Btc = benzene-1,3,5-tricarboxylic acid), have been isolated from parallel hydrothermal reactions of ZnSO4 and H2Bpz with H2Tph, H2Iph, and H3Btc, respectively. These crystalline solids have been structurally defined, of which 1 was revealed to construct in a 3D architecture with porosity. Interestingly, because of its large porosity, 1 allows the concurrent 2-fold interpenetration and inclusion of free H2Bpz as guest molecule. In contrast to 1, polymer 2 structures in a 2D framework of note for containing both neutral and deprotonated H2Bpz as μ2-and μ4-bridging linkers, respectively. This case demonstrates a rare usage of H2Bpz as ligand in the construction of MOFs. The partial deprotonation of H2Bpz may be a consequence of less acidity of H2Iph than H2Tph, by which the influence of a second ligand on the reactivity of the main ligand is reified. Likewise, 3 is also assembled in a 2D framework, containing H2Bpz and monoacid HBtc2- as ligands, which indicates the stronger acidity of H3Btc. Moreover, to probe the effect of substitution of second ligands, we have investigated the luminescence of 1−3 in the solid state at room temperature, revealing that the polymers are photoluminescent and their emissions are varied with the alteration of second ligands.
elements.clean_text: Three new coordination polymers, {[Zn(H2Bpz)(Tph)]⋅1/2(H2Bpz)} n  (1), [Zn 2 (H2Bpz)(Bpz)(Iph)] n  (2), and {[Zn 2 (H2Bpz)(HBtc) 2 (H2O) 2 ]⋅7/6(H2O)} n  (3) (H2Bpz = 3,3‘,5,5‘-tetramethyl-4,4‘-bipyrazole; H2Tph = terephthalic acid; H2Iph = isophthalic acid; H3Btc = benzene-1,3,5-tricarboxylic acid), have been isolated from parallel hydrothermal reactions of ZnSO4 and H2Bpz with H2Tph, H2Iph, and H3Btc, respectively. These crystalline solids have been structurally defined, of which 1 was revealed to construct in a 3D architecture with porosity. Interestingly, because of its large porosity, 1 allows the concurrent 2-fold interpenetration and inclusion of free H2Bpz as guest molecule. In contrast to 1, polymer 2 structures in a 2D framework of note for containing both neutral and deprotonated H2Bpz as μ2-and μ4-bridging linkers, respectively. This case demonstrates a rare usage of H2Bpz as ligand in the construction of MOFs. The partial deprotonation of H2Bpz may be a consequence of less acidity of H2Iph than H2Tph, by which the influence of a second ligand on the reactivity of the main ligand is reified. Likewise, 3 is also assembled in a 2D framework, containing H2Bpz and monoacid HBtc2- as ligands, which indicates the stronger acidity of H3Btc. Moreover, to probe the effect of substitution of second ligands, we have investigated the luminescence of 1-3 in the solid state at room temperature, revealing that the polymers are photoluminescent and their emissions are varied with the alteration of second ligands.

elements.content: Reactions of ZnSO4, H2Bpz, and H2Tph or H2Iph or H3Btc, respectively, under the same conditions, afforded three novel coordination polymers, 1−3, whose diverse structures illustrate the second ligand-directed assembly of MOFs.
elements.clean_text: Reactions of ZnSO4, H2Bpz, and H2Tph or H2Iph or H3Btc, respectively, under the same conditions, afforded three novel coordination polymers, 1-3, whose diverse structures illustrate the second ligand-directed assembly of MOFs.

elements.content: Controlled assembly of metal−organic frameworks (MOFs) through rational design is a topic of great interest to crystal engineering, because the endeavor directs to developing a universal logic for molecular architecture and fabricating the MOFs with desired structure and physical properties. However, it is realized that the assembly of MOFs is highly influenced, not only by the coordination preferences of building blocks, but also by the nonconstitutional factors, e.g., solvent, coexisting species, reaction stoichiometry, and temperature. In other words, to predict a target structure merely on the basis of the information of building blocks is almost impossible. Even so, the attempt to probe the effect of the reaction parameters on assembly of MOFs has never been retracted; on the contrary, it becomes a central interest of contemporary synthetic coordination chemistry because understanding of assembly principle is a precondition of design of MOFs. A routine of the efforts is to perform a series of reactions in similar conditions with only one factor varied. In such a case, the diversity in assembly and functionality of MOFs can be exclusively attributed to the change of the factor.
elements.clean_text:
Introduction

Controlled assembly of metal-organic frameworks (MOFs) through rational design is a topic of great interest to crystal engineering, because the endeavor directs to developing a universal logic for molecular architecture and fabricating the MOFs with desired structure and physical properties. However, it is realized that the assembly of MOFs is highly influenced, not only by the coordination preferences of building blocks, but also by the nonconstitutional factors, e.g., solvent, coexisting species, reaction stoichiometry, and temperature. In other words, to predict a target structure merely on the basis of the information of building blocks is almost impossible. Even so, the attempt to probe the effect of the reaction parameters on assembly of MOFs has never been retracted; on the contrary, it becomes a central interest of contemporary synthetic coordination chemistry because understanding of assembly principle is a precondition of design of MOFs. A routine of the efforts is to perform a series of reactions in similar conditions with only one factor varied. In such a case, the diversity in assembly and functionality of MOFs can be exclusively attributed to the change of the factor.

elements.content: Recently, the authors reported a room-temperature photoluminescent Cu(I) coordination polymer derived from 3,3‘,5,5‘-tetramethyl- 4,4‘-bipyrazole (H2Bpz). As a part of the endeavor to fabricate luminous crystalline solids, we adopted the bipyrazole ligand as primary ligand, together with aromatic multicarboxylic acids H2Tph, H2Iph, and H3Btc (Scheme ) as second ligand, to react with ZnSO4, where the acids were chosen for their possessing various coordination geometries and modes. As consequence, three crystalline solids 1−3 were isolated and structurally characterized. Their structures show the common virtues of porous networks, such as multidimensional construction, interpenetration, encapsulation etc., as well as the influence of second ligands on the assembly of MOFs. To the best of our knowledge, the MOFs, constructed from H2Bpz and acid ligands, have rarely been documented. Herein, we intend to describe their novel structures and solid-state photoluminescence.
elements.clean_text: Recently, the authors reported a room-temperature photoluminescent Cu(I) coordination polymer derived from 3,3‘,5,5‘-tetramethyl- 4,4‘-bipyrazole (H2Bpz). As a part of the endeavor to fabricate luminous crystalline solids, we adopted the bipyrazole ligand as primary ligand, together with aromatic multicarboxylic acids H2Tph, H2Iph, and H3Btc (Scheme ) as second ligand, to react with ZnSO4, where the acids were chosen for their possessing various coordination geometries and modes. As consequence, three crystalline solids 1-3 were isolated and structurally characterized. Their structures show the common virtues of porous networks, such as multidimensional construction, interpenetration, encapsulation etc., as well as the influence of second ligands on the assembly of MOFs. To the best of our knowledge, the MOFs, constructed from H2Bpz and acid ligands, have rarely been documented. Herein, we intend to describe their novel structures and solid-state photoluminescence.

elements.content: General Procedure The carboxylic acids and solvents were purchased commercially and used as received. H2Bpz was synthesized by the literature method and crystallized in hydrated form (see the Supporting Information). IR spectra of all samples (KBr) were recorded on a Nicolet Avatar 360. Microanalyses were performed by a Perkin-Elmer 2400 Analyzer. Thermogravimetric (TG) analyses were carried out on a SHIMADZU TGA-50. Luminescence was measured on a Perkin-Elmer LS 55 spectrometer.
elements.clean_text:
Experimental Section

 General Procedure The carboxylic acids and solvents were purchased commercially and used as received. H2Bpz was synthesized by the literature method and crystallized in hydrated form (see the Supporting Information). IR spectra of all samples (KBr) were recorded on a Nicolet Avatar 360. Microanalyses were performed by a Perkin-Elmer 2400 Analyzer. Thermogravimetric (TG) analyses were carried out on a SHIMADZU TGA-50. Luminescence was measured on a Perkin-Elmer LS 55 spectrometer.

elements.content: Synthesis of {[Zn(H 2 Bpz)(Tph)]·1/2(H 2 Bpz)} n (1). An aqueous mixture of ZnSO4·7H2O (0.0575 g, 0.2mmol), H2Bpz (0.0381 g, 0.2mmol) and H2Tph (0.0166 g, 0.1mmol) in a Teflon-lined reactor was heated to 120 °C, kept at the temperature for 48 h, and after this time, cooled to room temperature at a rate of −5 °C/h. Colorless crystals of 1 suitable for X-ray diffraction were collected in yield of ca. 75%. Anal. Calcd (%) for 1 (C23H25N6O4Zn):  C, 53.70; H, 4.86; N, 16.34. Found (%):  C, 53.68; H, 4.91; N, 16.32. IR (KBr, cm-1):  3204(m), 3078(w), 2921(w), 2360(w), 1626(s), 1595(m), 1539(w), 1382(s), 1356(s), 1295(w), 1186(w), 886(w), 752(m).

elements.content: Synthesis of [Zn 2 (H 2 Bpz)(Bpz)(Iph)] n (2). The compound was prepared comparably to the synthesis of 1, but taking H2Iph as second ligand instead of H2Tph. It was collected as colorless crystals in a yield of ca. 40%. Anal. Calcd (%) for 2 (C14H13N4O2Zn):  C, 33.05; H, 1.94; N, 7.71. Found (%):  C, 33.08; H, 1.96; N, 7.68. IR (KBr, cm-1):  3039(w), 2956 (w), 2930(w), 1613(s), 1543(s), 1474(m), 1435(s), 1378(s), 1297(m), 1183(w), 1157(w), 1060(m), 1039(m), 1000(w), 752(m), 713(s).

elements.content: Synthesis of {[Zn 2 (H 2 Bpz)(HBtc) 2 (H 2 O) 2 ]·7/6(H 2 O)} n (3). The preparation of 3 is similar to that of 1, but using H3Btc (0.0211 g, 0.1mmol) as second ligand instead. The treatment afforded the crystals of 3 in yield of ca 50%. Anal. Calcd (%) for 3 (C28H28.33N4O15.16Zn2):  C, 42.30; H, 3.57; N, 7.05. Found (%):  C, 42.35; H, 3.54; N, 7.0 8. IR (KBr, cm-1):  3086(w), 2923(w), 1709(s), 1691(s), 1617(s), 1560(s), 1448(m), 1370(s), 1257(s), 1191(m), 1104(w), 1074(m), 765(m), 726(s).

elements.content: Crystallography. X-ray crystal structure determinations were performed on a Bruker-AXS SMART CCD area detector diffractometer with the crystals glued at the end of a glass fiber. Data collections were carried out at 293 K using a ω-scan with a width of 0.3° and Mo−Kα radiation (λ = 0.71073 Å). Absorption corrections were carried out utilizing the SADABS routine. The structures were solved by direct methods and further refined by full-matrix least-square refinements on the basis of F 2 using SHELXTL programs. All nonhydrogen atoms were refined with anisotropic thermal parameters, and all hydrogen atoms were included in calculated positions and refined with isotropic thermal parameters riding on those of the parent atoms. In the structural refinement of 3, the site occupation factor of 1 H2O guest (1/6) was adjusted to give reasonable thermal parameters, and thus in this formula appears 7/6 crystalline water molecules. More crystallographic details of 1−3 are given in Table , and the selected bond parameters are listed in Table .

All nonhydrogen atoms were refined with anisotropic thermal parameters, and all hydrogen atoms were included in calculated positions and refined with isotropic thermal parameters riding on those of the parent atoms. In the structural refinement of 3, the site occupation factor of 1 H2O guest (1/6) was adjusted to give reasonable thermal parameters, and thus in this formula appears 7/6 crystalline water molecules. More crystallographic details of 1-3 are given in Table , and the selected bond parameters are listed in Table .

Syntheses. The colorless block-shaped crystals of 1−3 for structural analysis were obtained from hydrothermal reactions of ZnSO4, H2Bpz with corresponding carboxylic acids. All the reactions were carried out under parallel conditions except for second ligands. In general, the diversity in the assembly and functions of 1−3 can be ascribed to the change of second ligands. Herein, zinc sulfate is used as metal source. Actually, using Zn(NO3)2 or Zn(ClO4)2 in the place of ZnSO4 can also afford the target compounds but in lower yields.
elements.clean_text:
Results and Discussion

 Syntheses. The colorless block-shaped crystals of 1-3 for structural analysis were obtained from hydrothermal reactions of ZnSO4, H2Bpz with corresponding carboxylic acids. All the reactions were carried out under parallel conditions except for second ligands. In general, the diversity in the assembly and functions of 1-3 can be ascribed to the change of second ligands. Herein, zinc sulfate is used as metal source. Actually, using Zn(NO3)2 or Zn(ClO4)2 in the place of ZnSO4 can also afford the target compounds but in lower yields.

elements.content: Structure Description. Compound 1 crystallized in a 3D supramolecule, composed of guest H2Bpz molecules and hosting neutral framework. In the framework of 1, the Zn(II) ions are uniform, each coordinated by two nitrogen atoms from two H2Bpz (Zn−N 1.9750(18)−2.0153(19)Å) and two oxygen atoms from two Tph2- (Zn−O 1.9050(17)−1.9485(16)Å) (Figure ). The metal-centered angles (101.4−116.6°) suggests a distorted tetrahedral coordination geometry for the Zn(II) center. Satisfying the electroneutrality of framework, the acid ligand, H2Tph molecules are assumed completely deprotonated and exist in dianionic form of Tph2-. Combination of H2Bpzand Tph2- and Zn(II) centers give two unique 1D zigzag chains, highlighted by different colors in Figure . One chain is extended by H2Bpz along c, with the two closest Zn(II) ions separated by 9.629 Å, whereas the other is led by Tph2- along a and the Zn···Zn separation is 9.629 Å across the single Tph2- bridge.
elements.clean_text: Structure Description. Compound 1 crystallized in a 3D supramolecule, composed of guest H2Bpz molecules and hosting neutral framework. In the framework of 1, the Zn(II) ions are uniform, each coordinated by two nitrogen atoms from two H2Bpz (Zn-N 1.9750(18)-2.0153(19)Å) and two oxygen atoms from two Tph2- (Zn-O 1.9050(17)-1.9485(16)Å) (Figure ). The metal-centered angles (101.4-116.6°) suggests a distorted tetrahedral coordination geometry for the Zn(II) center. Satisfying the electroneutrality of framework, the acid ligand, H2Tph molecules are assumed completely deprotonated and exist in dianionic form of Tph2-. Combination of H2Bpzand Tph2- and Zn(II) centers give two unique 1D zigzag chains, highlighted by different colors in Figure . One chain is extended by H2Bpz along c, with the two closest Zn(II) ions separated by 9.629 Å, whereas the other is led by Tph2- along a and the Zn⋅⋅⋅Zn separation is 9.629 Å across the single Tph2- bridge.

elements.content: View of1 depicting the coordination environment around the Zn(II) center; the hydrogen atoms are omitted for clarity.
elements.clean_text: 1  View of1 depicting the coordination environment around the Zn(II) center; the hydrogen atoms are omitted for clarity.

elements.content: Two types of zigzag chain assembly from H2Bpz or Tph2- and Zn(II) atoms.
elements.clean_text: 2  Two types of zigzag chain assembly from H2Bpz or Tph2- and Zn(II) atoms.

elements.content: With simplifying the Zn(II) as nod and H2Bpz and Tph2- as linkers, a diamondoid [66] topology will be obtained for 1. Because of the spacer ligand adopted, a single framework possesses great voids (Figure ) with a free volume of 75.2%, larger than that of the Zn(II)−Tph2- framework (55.8%). Typically, the large porosity will lead to interpenetration or inclusion. This is evidenced by the 2-fold interpenetration of 1 as demonstrated in Figure . On the basis of a PLATON(−VOID) calculation, the interpenetrated frameworks are still very open, with 49.6% filled space and 30% potential solvent area, thus allowing encapsulation of free H2Bpz as guest molecules (see the Supporting Information, Figure S1). The dual functionalized framework of 1 demonstrates a rare case of concurrent inclusion and interpenetration and, at the same time, confirms that a high porous construction must be stabilized by either inclusion and/or interpenetration. Moreover, the hosting frameworks of 1 show moderate hydrogen bonds to guest H2Bpz molecules, defined by the N···O distances ranging from 2.795 to 2.791 Å. The intricate interactions, together with the concurrent inclusion and interpenetration in 1, stress its importance in understanding the behaviors of porous MOFs.
elements.clean_text: With simplifying the Zn(II) as nod and H2Bpz and Tph2- as linkers, a diamondoid [66] topology will be obtained for 1.  Because of the spacer ligand adopted, a single framework possesses great voids (Figure ) with a free volume of 75.2%, larger than that of the Zn(II)-Tph2- framework (55.8%). Typically, the large porosity will lead to interpenetration or inclusion. This is evidenced by the 2-fold interpenetration of 1 as demonstrated in Figure . On the basis of a PLATON(-VOID) calculation, the interpenetrated frameworks are still very open, with 49.6% filled space and 30% potential solvent area, thus allowing encapsulation of free H2Bpz as guest molecules (see the Supporting Information, Figure S1). The dual functionalized framework of 1 demonstrates a rare case of concurrent inclusion and interpenetration and, at the same time, confirms that a high porous construction must be stabilized by either inclusion and/or interpenetration. Moreover, the hosting frameworks of 1 show moderate hydrogen bonds to guest H2Bpz molecules, defined by the N⋅⋅⋅O distances ranging from 2.795  to 2.791 Å. The intricate interactions, together with the concurrent inclusion and interpenetration in 1, stress its importance in understanding the behaviors of porous MOFs.

elements.content: Compound 2 was obtained by using H2Iph as the second ligand in place of H2Tph. Use of the m-isomer results in a 2D structure, composed of Zn(II), Iph2-, H2Bpz, and Bpz2-. As demonstrated in Figure , each Zn(II) atom in 2, similar to that in 1, is tetrahedrally coordinated but differently surrounded by one N atoms from H2Bpz, two N atoms from anionic Bpz2-, and one O atom from the carboxylate of Iph2-. The Iph2- in 2, in contrast to the linear extended Tph2- in 1, is ⊂-shaped and possibly stops the extension along b, thus resulting in construction of a 2D architecture (Figure and the Supporting Information, Figure S2). At the same time, because a much shorter space ligand of Iph2- is employed in comparison with Tph2- in 1, the free voids have been sharply reduced and there is only 8.1% of area left for filling potential solvents. It is worth noting that the H2Bpz ligands are partly deprotonated and exist in both H2Bpz and Bpz2- forms. The current fashion is really a rare case in the construction of MOFs. More interestingly, presence of tetradentate Bpz2-, in combination with Zn(II) ions, give the twist-chair-shaped dizinc (N4Zn2) loops (see the Supporting Information, Figure S3); on the other hand, the combination of bitopic H2Bpz and tetratopic Bpz2- ligands with metal ions leads to a right-handed helix as shown in Figure , possessing a 21 screw axis parallel to c with a pitch of 15 Å. To a common knowledge, the partial deprotonation of H2Bpz can be ascribed to the less acidity of H2Iph (pKa1 3.62) than H2Tph (pKa1 3.54), by which the influence of second ligand (H2Iph) on the reactivity of the primary ligand H2Bpz is illustrated.
elements.clean_text: Compound 2 was obtained by using H2Iph as the second ligand in place of H2Tph. Use of the m-isomer results in a 2D structure, composed of Zn(II), Iph2-, H2Bpz, and Bpz2-. As demonstrated in Figure , each Zn(II) atom in 2, similar to that in 1, is tetrahedrally coordinated but differently surrounded by one N atoms from H2Bpz, two N atoms from anionic Bpz2-, and one O atom from the carboxylate of Iph2-. The Iph2- in 2, in contrast to the linear extended Tph2- in 1, is ⊂-shaped and possibly stops the extension along b, thus resulting in construction of a 2D architecture (Figure  and the Supporting Information, Figure S2). At the same time, because a much shorter space ligand of Iph2- is employed in comparison with Tph2- in 1, the free voids have been sharply reduced and there is only 8.1% of area left for filling potential solvents. It is worth noting that the H2Bpz ligands are partly deprotonated and exist in both H2Bpz and Bpz2- forms. The current fashion is really a rare case in the construction of MOFs. More interestingly, presence of tetradentate Bpz2-, in combination with Zn(II) ions, give the twist-chair-shaped dizinc (N4Zn2) loops (see the Supporting Information, Figure S3); on the other hand, the combination of bitopic H2Bpz and tetratopic Bpz2- ligands with metal ions leads to a right-handed helix as shown in Figure , possessing a 21 screw axis parallel to c with a pitch of 15 Å. To a common knowledge, the partial deprotonation of H2Bpz can be ascribed to the less acidity of H2Iph (pKa1 3.62) than H2Tph (pKa1 3.54), by which the influence of second ligand (H2Iph) on the reactivity of the primary ligand H2Bpz is illustrated.

elements.content: 3 was synthesized by using a trinary acid, H3Btc (pKa1 2.12) as second ligand instead. The stronger acidity of H3Btc results in its appearance as monoacidic HBtc2- in the assembly of 3. Single-crystal X-ray diffraction reveals that 3 is a 2D porous network, assembled from Zn(II), H2Bpz, HBtc2-, and H2O. As shown in Figure , the zinc ions, according to their coordination numbers, can be sorted into Zn1 and Zn2, of which the Zn1 is four-coordinated with two oxygen atoms from carboxylate groups (Zn1−O 1.931(3)−1.962(3) Å), one nitrogen from bipyrozle (Zn1−N 2.002(3) Å), and an oxygen from an aqua donor (Zn1−O1W 2.095(3) Å). The Zn2 is five-coordinated with one N atom from H2Bpz (Zn2−N 1.990(3) Å), three O atoms from carboxylate groups, and one O atom from a water molecule. The coordination geometries of Zn1 and Zn2 can be assumed to be distorted tetrahedron and triangle bipyramid, respectively. And the building units, HBtc2-, adopt two different coordination fashions, one as a ⊂-shaped bitopic bidentate ligand (Figure A), similar to Iph in 2, and the other as a Y-shaped bitopic tridentate ligand (Figure B). Figure A depicts the union of bidentate HBtc2- and Zn(II), a linear array, which is rather different from the union of tridentate HBtc2- and Zn(II) in a ring catena, as shown in Figure B, including the chairlike (C2O4Zn2) rings with Zn···Zn separation of 3.75 Å. The diverse roles of HBtc2-, on one hand, show the variability of the symmetry and coordination mode of ligands, and on the other hand, clarify the influence of the second ligand on the assembly of the MOF. Overall, because of the angular fashion of HBtc2- adopted in the construction of 3, similar to Iph2- in 2, compound 3 also displays the porosity with 4% free area, which can be filled by potential solvents. As expected, most voids have been occupied by crystalline water molecules. Functionally, the crystalline waters get stabilize by forming intricate H-bonding. In addition, the interlayer O−H···O hydrogen bonds, forming among the carboxylate oxygens, aqua ligands, and crystalline water molecules, play a vital role in determining the crystal packing and in the construction of the extended 3D supramolecular network of 3 (see the Supporting Information, Figure S4).

As shown in Figure , the zinc ions, according to their coordination numbers, can be sorted into Zn1 and Zn2, of which the Zn1 is four-coordinated with two oxygen atoms from carboxylate groups (Zn1-O 1.931(3)-1.962(3) Å), one nitrogen from bipyrozle (Zn1-N 2.002(3) Å), and an oxygen from an aqua donor (Zn1-O1W 2.095(3) Å). The Zn2 is five-coordinated with one N atom from H2Bpz (Zn2-N 1.990(3) Å), three O atoms from carboxylate groups, and one O atom from a water molecule. The coordination geometries of Zn1 and Zn2 can be assumed to be distorted tetrahedron and triangle bipyramid, respectively. And the building units, HBtc2-, adopt two different coordination fashions, one as a ⊂-shaped bitopic bidentate ligand (Figure A), similar to Iph in 2, and the other as a Y-shaped bitopic tridentate ligand (Figure B). Figure A depicts the union of bidentate HBtc2- and Zn(II), a linear array, which is rather different from the union of tridentate HBtc2- and Zn(II) in a ring catena, as shown in Figure B, including the chairlike (C2O4Zn2) rings with Zn⋅⋅⋅Zn separation of 3.75 Å. The diverse roles of HBtc2-, on one hand, show the variability of the symmetry and coordination mode of ligands, and on the other hand, clarify the influence of the second ligand on the assembly of the MOF. Overall, because of the angular fashion of HBtc2- adopted in the construction of 3, similar to Iph2- in 2, compound 3 also displays the porosity with 4% free area, which can be filled by potential solvents. elements.content: Two types of chains directed by the HBtc- ligand in a ⊂ shape (A) and in a Y shape (B).
elements.clean_text: 9  Two types of chains directed by the HBtc- ligand in a ⊂ shape (A) and in a Y shape (B).

elements.content: Thermogravimetric (TG) Characterization. Structural analysis has revealed that the H2Bpz molecules in 1 act as building units of MOFs as well as guest molecules. In principle, the differently functionalized H2Bpz molecules should be discriminable by their responses to heat. The speculation is confirmed by the TG curve of 1, displayed in Figure , in comparison with that of 2H2Bpz·H2O. In the shown temperature window, the hydrated ligand, 2H2Bpz·H2O, presents a curve, indicating two weight losses starting, respectively, from 120 and 198.7 °C. By the proximity of weight loss ratios (4.12 and 94.45%) to the calculated contents of water (4.52%) and H2Bpz (95.48%), they are attributed, respectively, to the loss of H2O and H2Bpz. It is worht noting that the leaving of water is obviously detained relative to liquid water. In a common sense, it is a result of stronger hydrogen bonding of H2O···H2Bpz than H2O···H2O in liquid water.
elements.clean_text: Thermogravimetric (TG) Characterization. Structural analysis has revealed that the H2Bpz molecules in 1 act as building units of MOFs as well as guest molecules. In principle, the differently functionalized H2Bpz molecules should be discriminable by their responses to heat. The speculation is confirmed by the TG curve of 1, displayed in Figure , in comparison with that of 2H2Bpz⋅H2O. In the shown temperature window, the hydrated ligand, 2H2Bpz⋅H2O, presents a curve, indicating two weight losses starting, respectively, from 120 and 198.7 °C. By the proximity of weight loss ratios (4.12 and 94.45%) to the calculated contents of water (4.52%) and H2Bpz (95.48%), they are attributed, respectively, to the loss of  H2O and H2Bpz. It is worht noting that the leaving of water is obviously detained relative to liquid water. In a common sense, it is a result of stronger hydrogen bonding of H2O⋅⋅⋅H2Bpz than H2O⋅⋅⋅H2O in liquid water.

elements.content: 2D extended architecture of3 along the b-axis. Methyl groups are omitted for clarity.
elements.clean_text: 10  2D extended architecture of3 along the b-axis. Methyl groups are omitted for clarity.

elements.content: TG curves of 2H2Bpz·H2O and 1 in comparison.
elements.clean_text: 11  TG curves of 2H2Bpz⋅H2O and 1 in comparison.

elements.content: The curve for 1 is relatively more intricate, showing at least three weight losses, starting from 220.4, 370, and 420 °C. It has been pointed out by Yaghi et al. that Tph2-, in combination with Zn(II), is stable up to 400 °C, and therefore we assign the first two slopes to the loss of H2Bpz. But, notably, the measured amount of included H2Bpz (7%) is not agreeable to that calculated (18%). Repeated measurements also gave no explanation to this discrepancy. In such a case, we assume the deficiency of included H2Bpz to be a result of defection of crystal lattice caused by the escape of inclusion H2Bpz. Comparing the desertion temperatures of coordinated-, included- and free-H2Bpz, it demonstrates that H2Bpz can get stabilization by both interactions of coordination and inclusion, but the interaction of the former is much stronger than that of the latter. Thus, it is concluded that the TG method can be used as a tool for studying the interactions of ligands.
elements.clean_text: The curve for 1 is relatively more intricate, showing at least three weight losses, starting from 220.4, 370, and 420 °C. It has been pointed out by Yaghi et al. that Tph2-, in combination with Zn(II), is stable up to 400 °C, and therefore we assign the first two slopes to the loss of H2Bpz. But, notably, the measured amount of included H2Bpz (7%) is not agreeable to that calculated (18%). Repeated measurements also gave no explanation to this discrepancy. In such a case, we assume the deficiency of included H2Bpz to be a result of defection of crystal lattice caused by the escape of inclusion H2Bpz. Comparing the desertion temperatures of coordinated-, included- and free-H2Bpz, it demonstrates that H2Bpz can get stabilization by both interactions of coordination and inclusion, but the interaction of the former is much stronger than that of the latter. Thus, it is concluded that the TG method can be used as a tool for studying the interactions of ligands.

elements.content: Photoluminescence. To probe the influence of second ligands on photobehaviors of the polymers, the luminescence of 1−3 was investigated in crystalline powder scattered on a plate intersecting with incidence at an angle of 45°. Upon excitation with 300 nm, 1−3 present strong emissions, as depicted in Figure . The curves resemble each other in shape, commonly composed of a lower-energy (LE) fore-shoulder and a higher-energy (HE) distinguishable peak (Figure ). As known to all, the d10-configured Zn(II) ion is electrochemically inert, and therefore, when coordinated by ligands, it cannot accept an electron from the ligand with its d-orbitals, nor donate an electron to the ligand. This being the case, the emissions of 1−3 are preferably ascribed to ligand-centered transitions rather than LMCT. Actually, the acid ligands in solid state have been proven emissive, presenting bands in the range (see the Supporting Information, Figures S5 and S6) co-incident with the emission band of 1−3. Moreover, the shapes of the emission band of the acid ligands are also similar to those of 1−3. Thus, we tentatively propose the origin of emissions of 1−3 from an intraligand π*−π transition. On the other hand, the ligand-based emissions of 1−3 are observed systematically bathochromically shifted from their corresponding acid ligands. The observation coincides with the prediction that deprotonation and coordination of ligand to d10 metal ion can significantly narrow the energy gap between the HOMOs and LUMOs. Even though no net charge transfer occurs between metal ion and ligands, coordination of ligand enlarges virtually the delocalization range of electrons of ligands. Furthermore, an overview of the spectra of three polymers indicates that the emissions of 1 and 2 are more alike, but that of 3 has a noticeable hypsochromic shift. This further confirms the assignments above because free H2Tph and H2Iph are analogous, having emission energies lower than that of H3Btc.

To probe the influence of second ligands on photobehaviors of the polymers, the luminescence of 1-3 was investigated in crystalline powder scattered on a plate intersecting with incidence at an angle of 45°. Upon excitation with 300 nm, 1-3 present strong emissions, as depicted in Figure . The curves resemble each other in shape, commonly composed of a lower-energy (LE) fore-shoulder and a higher-energy (HE) distinguishable peak (Figure ). As known to all, the d10-configured Zn(II) ion is electrochemically inert, and therefore, when coordinated by ligands, it cannot accept an electron from the ligand with its d-orbitals, nor donate an electron to the ligand. This being the case, the emissions of 1-3 are preferably ascribed to ligand-centered transitions rather  than LMCT. Actually, the acid ligands in solid state have been proven emissive, presenting bands in the range (see the Supporting Information, Figures S5 and S6) co-incident with the emission band of 1-3. Moreover, the shapes of the emission band of the acid ligands are also similar to those of 1-3. Thus, we tentatively propose the origin of emissions of 1-3 from an intraligand π*-π transition. On the other hand, the ligand-based emissions of 1-3 are observed systematically bathochromically shifted from their corresponding acid ligands. The observation coincides with the prediction that deprotonation and coordination of ligand to d10 metal ion can significantly narrow the energy gap between the HOMOs and LUMOs. Even though no net charge transfer occurs between metal ion and ligands, coordination of ligand enlarges virtually the delocalization range of electrons of ligands. Furthermore, an overview of the spectra of three polymers indicates that the emissions of 1 and 2 are more alike, but that of 3 has a noticeable hypsochromic shift. This further confirms the assignments above because free H2Tph and H2Iph are analogous, having emission energies lower than that of H3Btc.

elements.content: Solid room-temperature photoluminescence spectra of1−3 under irradiation of 300 nm.
elements.clean_text: 12  Solid room-temperature photoluminescence spectra of1-3 under irradiation of 300 nm.

elements.content: The reactions of ZnSO4 and H2Bpz with H2Tph and H2Iph and H3Btc under parallel conditions afforded three intriguing MOFs. Their diverse architectures illustrate the interests of MOFs, such as supramolecular host−guest and hydrogen bonding interactions, network interpenetration, heterochain construction, different dimensional framework and molecular topology, etc. More relevant to our purpose, the structures demonstrate the influence of a second ligand on the assembly of MOFs. Concretely, the cases prove that the carboxylic acids affect structures of the MOFs not only through providing geometrically different linkers but also through influencing the reactivity on primary ligand.
elements.clean_text:
Conclusion

The reactions of ZnSO4 and H2Bpz with H2Tph and H2Iph and H3Btc under parallel conditions afforded three intriguing MOFs. Their diverse architectures illustrate the interests of MOFs, such as supramolecular host-guest and hydrogen bonding interactions, network interpenetration, heterochain construction, different dimensional framework and molecular topology, etc. More relevant to our purpose, the structures demonstrate the influence of a second ligand on the assembly of MOFs. Concretely, the cases prove that the carboxylic acids affect structures of the MOFs not only through providing geometrically different linkers but also through influencing the reactivity on primary ligand.

elements.content: Full crystallographic data in CIF format for compounds 1−3. Additional figures of the crystal structures of 1−3 (PDF). This material is available free of charge via the Internet at http://pubs.acs.org.
elements.clean_text:
Supporting Information Available 

Full crystallographic data in CIF format for compounds 1-3. Additional figures of the crystal structures of 1-3 (PDF). This material is available free of charge via the Internet at http://pubs.acs.org.

cln_elements.content:
Synthesis of {[Zn(H 2 Bpz)(Tph)]·1/2(H 2 Bpz)} n (1). An aqueous mixture of ZnSO4·7H2O (0.0575 g, 0.2mmol), H2Bpz (0.0381 g, 0.2mmol) and H2Tph (0.0166 g, 0.1mmol) in a Teflon-lined reactor was heated to 120 °C, kept at the temperature for 48 h, and after this time, cooled to room temperature at a rate of −5 °C/h. Colorless crystals of 1 suitable for X-ray diffraction were collected in yield of ca. 75%. Anal. Calcd (%) for 1 (C23H25N6O4Zn):  C, 53.70; H, 4.86; N, 16.34. Found (%):  C, 53.68; H, 4.91; N, 16.32. IR (KBr, cm-1):  3204(m), 3078(w), 2921(w), 2360(w), 1626(s), 1595(m), 1539(w), 1382(s), 1356(s), 1295(w), 1186(w), 886(w), 752(m).

Synthesis of [Zn 2 (H 2 Bpz)(Bpz)(Iph)] n (2). The compound was prepared comparably to the synthesis of 1, but taking H2Iph as second ligand instead of H2Tph. It was collected as colorless crystals in a yield of ca. 40%. Anal. Calcd (%) for 2 (C14H13N4O2Zn):  C, 33.05; H, 1.94; N, 7.71. Found (%):  C, 33.08; H, 1.96; N, 7.68. IR (KBr, cm-1):  3039(w), 2956 (w), 2930(w), 1613(s), 1543(s), 1474(m), 1435(s), 1378(s), 1297(m), 1183(w), 1157(w), 1060(m), 1039(m), 1000(w), 752(m), 713(s).

Synthesis of {[Zn 2 (H 2 Bpz)(HBtc) 2 (H 2 O) 2 ]·7/6(H 2 O)} n (3). The preparation of 3 is similar to that of 1, but using H3Btc (0.0211 g, 0.1mmol) as second ligand instead. The treatment afforded the crystals of 3 in yield of ca 50%. Anal. Calcd (%) for 3 (C28H28.33N4O15.16Zn2):  C, 42.30; H, 3.57; N, 7.05. Found (%):  C, 42.35; H, 3.54; N, 7.0 8. IR (KBr, cm-1):  3086(w), 2923(w), 1709(s), 1691(s), 1617(s), 1560(s), 1448(m), 1370(s), 1257(s), 1191(m), 1104(w), 1074(m), 765(m), 726(s).

cln_elements.content:
With simplifying the Zn(II) as nod and H2Bpz and Tph2- as linkers, a diamondoid [66] topology will be obtained for 1. Because of the spacer ligand adopted, a single framework possesses great voids (Figure ) with a free volume of 75.2%, larger than that of the Zn(II)−Tph2- framework (55.8%). Typically, the large porosity will lead to interpenetration or inclusion. This is evidenced by the 2-fold interpenetration of 1 as demonstrated in Figure . On the basis of a PLATON(−VOID) calculation, the interpenetrated frameworks are still very open, with 49.6% filled space and 30% potential solvent area, thus allowing encapsulation of free H2Bpz as guest molecules (see the Supporting Information, Figure S1). The dual functionalized framework of 1 demonstrates a rare case of concurrent inclusion and interpenetration and, at the same time, confirms that a high porous construction must be stabilized by either inclusion and/or interpenetration. Moreover, the hosting frameworks of 1 show moderate hydrogen bonds to guest H2Bpz molecules, defined by the N···O distances ranging from 2.795 to 2.791 Å. The intricate interactions, together with the concurrent inclusion and interpenetration in 1, stress its importance in understanding the behaviors of porous MOFs.

Thermogravimetric (TG) Characterization. Structural analysis has revealed that the H2Bpz molecules in 1 act as building units of MOFs as well as guest molecules. In principle, the differently functionalized H2Bpz molecules should be discriminable by their responses to heat. The speculation is confirmed by the TG curve of 1, displayed in Figure , in comparison with that of 2H2Bpz·H2O. In the shown temperature window, the hydrated ligand, 2H2Bpz·H2O, presents a curve, indicating two weight losses starting, respectively, from 120 and 198.7 °C. By the proximity of weight loss ratios (4.12 and 94.45%) to the calculated contents of water (4.52%) and H2Bpz (95.48%), they are attributed, respectively, to the loss of H2O and H2Bpz. It is worht noting that the leaving of water is obviously detained relative to liquid water. In a common sense, it is a result of stronger hydrogen bonding of H2O···H2Bpz than H2O···H2O in liquid water.

decomposition temperature.condition: corresponding to the departure of guest molecules

decomposition temperature.type: gradual removal of coordinated water molecules
